Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 3-6 hours
I probably spent 3-5 hours per week on the reading and weekly summaries. I spent another several hours per week chipping away at the final project.
I spent 2 - 3 hours per week on reading and writing the critical summaries, with about an extra hour when I was leading discussion.
Weekly homework approximately 2 hours. The systematic review, if spaced out over the semester, also takes a few hours of work per week.
8 hours

Wonderful class! The topic is fascinating, the assignments and readings each week were manageable and improved my writing, and having the opportunity to do a full systematic review with a partner was so satisfying!
Good but the weekly reading summaries were excessive and unnecessary.

Strengths: This class is just interesting if you have any interest in maternal and child health. I liked that the weeks were divided into topics that we explored in great depth. The deadlines for different aspects of the final paper were useful and kept me on track.

Weaknesses: The midterm. I honestly didn't and still don't understand its purpose (despite doing quite well on it). In no world would you have to regurgitate memorized knowledge from a single article and complete a whole exam about it. We already did enough work on the weekly summaries, and the midterm did not enhance or build upon any other skills in the class. It also isn't necessary--we have plenty of grades for other assignments as is. If you are going to keep it, at least give students the ability to have the original article with them while completing the midterm. Epi 2 does it that way, and it works out fine.

Strengths: 
Instructor had hands-on experience in the field, which made a lot of the lectures feel so much more meaningful (i.e., I wasn't just learning about theories of maternal and child public health nutrition, but had the opportunity to better understand how they applied in practice)
I thought this was an engaging course, with interesting topic material and discussions.
Excellent course, very informative. I enjoyed learning more about Rafael's own work.
This course was extremely informative and well structured! I enjoyed the work and really thought that completing a systematic review was an asset to the course as it helped me learn a lot.

Strengths: This is an interesting class, especially when you hear about the professor's experiences on guidelines and interventions.

Weaknesses: It is not a technical class. You wont become an expert or extremely knowledgeable on issues regarding maternal and child nutrition. 

The evaluation method warrants improvement. The midterm is an epi II exam, which seems inappropriate since this is not an epi class. In addition, the evaluation method seems opinion-based (also inappropriate). A systematic review is 50% of your grade, however, you never actually learn anything about systematic reviews or how to conduct them. Only around 10% of the whole semester is dedicated to this.
Instructor is wonderful and very interesting course material. Relevant and correct amount of reading.

Rafael is great, incredibly knowledgeable about the topic, and super interested in helping students. He was too busy though and always seemed to be running to and from class. Learned a lot in this course and liked the format forcing us to read the articles and present.

I was really looking forward to learning a great deal in the course, particularly in relation to systematic reviews. We received a lot of information on child and maternal health, which was great, and we completed systematic reviews as a final project, but we did not learn much about the systematic review process. Systematic reviews are highly regarded because they follow a very specific and rigid methodology. Each week, in the course, we examined various peer reviewed articles on maternal and child health, but we did not routinely focus on systematic reviews. Since systematic reviews were 60% of out grade and Professor Perez-Escamilla has a lot of great experience surrounding systematic reviews, a systematic review focus would have been much appreciated. The side course session on the systematic review process, which was not mandatory, was not enough.

An absolutely wonderful professor. He is so knowledgeable and passionate- he cares about his work and his students. My only complaint is that I wish he didn't had to miss class for traveling-- I would have loved more lectures with him!
Excellent. Very knowledgeable and engaging. Would have loved to discuss more challenging topics.

Rafael is a wonderful instructor. He is kind, thoughtful and cares deeply about his students. I really appreciated when he brought his real world experience and projects into the classroom, because it helped reinforce the material.

- Very knowledgeable 
- Provided feedback on each critical review summary 
- Provided good feedback for the systematic review that helped us polish and refine for the final submission.
Prof. Perez-Escamilla is a great instructor who clearly cares deeply about his students and about his work.
Excellent Professor, very approachable and insightful.
I was extremely impressed by the professors commitment to the course when he had a lot of other positions. He even would skype students to discuss things with them if he was out of town.

Strengths: interesting experience, knowledgeable and passionate.
Weaknesses: Sometimes can be narrow-, strong-minded or absolutistic, this can be reflected in your evaluation if your opinions are different or your background questions some of the things that are being discussed in class.
Rafael is great!! Very knowledgable and a sensitive, fair-minded instructor.
Great professor, not enough time.
I think Professor Perez-Escamilla is very accomplished and knowledgable, but I wish that he would have shared his personal systematic review process experience with us.

A fantastic course in terms of both subject area (really interesting topics each week, didn't feel repetitive though topics did relate to one another) and skills you will gain (systematic review, critically reviewing articles, presentation skills on papers and your review). Would definitely recommend!
Good, recommend especially if you want the opportunity to write a narrative systematic review as it is a good skill to learn.

If you are interested in maternal and child health, I recommend taking this course. The systematic review is a lot of work, but you will gain valuable skills and you will get to know Rafael really well, which is always a treat.

This course on maternal-child public health nutrition is predominantly lecture-based, though class opens with student-led discussions on the readings.  You'll provide a weekly, critical review summary that provides a good opportunity to engage with the material for the course.  Final systematic review does take a lot of work, however it helps that the assignments are spread out throughout the semester and you receive a lot of guidance along the way.  Would recommend this course.
I thought this was an engaging course, with interesting topic material and discussions. Prof. Perez-Escamilla is a great instructor who clearly cares deeply about his students and about his work.
I would definitely recommend, especially for students interested in learning more about global nutrition.
Great! Definitely take if you are interested in the topic!
I am not sure I would recommend this course. It is an enjoyable class to sit in, but does not give you enough for what you are required to put in.
I would very much recommend this course. If you have an interest in MCPHN-- the learning objectives are very clear and realized. Exercise of systematic review is also valuable.
Great course if interested in child and maternal nutrition talking on all the big topics and interest of Rafael. Get exposure to the always running man. Awesome work. Yes, would recommend.

This course is a good overview of maternal and child health with a very focus on breastfeeding. If students are interested in maternal and child health, and specifically the role that breastfeeding plays in the promotion of maternal and child health, they should take this course. Students should not take this course if they really want a deep dive into the systematic review process and if they are looking to employ systematic review methodology in their final thesis project.
